ranked_diseases.explanation: Presents with ataxia, hyporeflexia, and dysarthria. Hypoalbuminemia can occur due to malabsorption. The neurological features match well with this treatable condition.
Features ataxia, hyporeflexia, dysarthria, and slow saccades (related to supranuclear gaze palsy). Age of onset fits. Athetosis less common but can occur.
Classic features include supranuclear vertical gaze palsy, ataxia, dysarthria, and movement disorders. Can present in adults. Hypoalbuminemia less typical.
Presents with ataxia, dysarthria, and ophthalmoplegia. Can have dystonia/athetosis. Hyporeflexia and hypoalbuminemia less typical but possible.
Features supranuclear gaze palsy, dysarthria, and ataxia. Typically presents later in life. Athetosis and hypoalbuminemia are atypical.
Can present with ataxia, hyporeflexia, and hypoalbuminemia due to fat malabsorption. Ophthalmoplegia possible. Movement disorders less common.
